Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Acquisition of an ICP-OES to Support Research and Education in the Environmental Geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
1530582
Rouff

This grant supports acquisition of an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) to be housed in the Department of Earth and Environmental Science at Rutgers University ? Newark. The ICP-OES would support research in environmental geochemistry that requires the ability to determine elemental concentrations in natural samples with low detection limits (ppm-ppb) and high precision. The investigators include early career faculty and an underrepresented geoscientist and the acquisition will support focused efforts to broaden the participation of underrepresented students in geoscience research through experiential learning in analytical geochemistry with relevance to issues of urban sustainability.

Research on trace metal interactions with a phosphate mineral precipitate (struvite) produced from human waste and the biogeochemical cycling of trace metals in soils will be facilitated by this acquisition.


***

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: An Agilent 5110 Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) was acquired to support research, education and outreach in the Department of Earth & Environmental Sciences (DEES), Rutgers University, Newark NJ (RU-N). The instrument provides rapid single and multi-elemental analyses of environmental and laboratory-generated samples.

Intellectual Merit: The ICP-OES was used for funded projects focused topics such as: contaminant and micronutrient metals in fertilizer recycled from wastes; cycling of iron and trace metals in flooded soils; monitoring of microbial induced soil strengthening by calcite precipitation. The instrument also supported a Fulbright international research project conducted by the PI. Access to ICP-OES eliminated the need for external analytical facilities, aided the development of additional research projects, and improved participation of both graduate and undergraduate students. Graduate researchers included Master's and PhD level students in the Departments of Earth & Environmental Sciences and Chemistry, and visiting international students from Brazil and China. Undergraduate researchers included those participating in funded projects, as well as visiting and in-house NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) summer and in-semester students.

Broader Impacts: The ICP-OES was used in undergraduate courses at both RU-N and nearby institutions. For example, students in an RU-N Soil Science course used the ICP-OES to determine contaminant contents in urban soils from the community; and students in an Essex County College (a local Community College) Environmental Science course used the instrument to analyse water samples from their homes. A major outreach component was a Public Participation in STEM Research (PPSR) supplemental project to evaluate heavy metal content and distribution in Newark Community Garden soils through engagement of Community Garden Managers and volunteers. The ICP-OES was also used for high school student projects as part of the American Association of Chemistry Teachers/American Chemical Society (AACT/ACS) Science Coaches program, and for various RU-N programs, such as Geoscience Summer Scholars, and t-STEM, targeted towards high school students. Due to the highly diverse RU-N student body, and the demographic make-up of Newark, NJ, groups underrepresented in STEM at all educational levels participated in research, education and outreach involving use of the ICP-OES.


Last Modified: 12/02/2019
Modified by: Ashaki A Rouff

Access to ICP-OES eliminated the need for external analytical facilities, aided the development of additional research projects, and improved participation of both graduate and undergraduate students. Due to the highly diverse RU-N student body, and the demographic make-up of Newark, NJ, groups underrepresented in STEM at all educational levels participated in research, education and outreach involving use of the ICP-OES.
